author: aigonza
title: CO2 registry for construction
description: CO2排出量の40%は建設業によるもので、ラタム地域では主要なCO2排出者の一つであり、各国の発展に伴い増加すると思われる。

f6_assessments.q0:
Disclaimer: my view points are shaped by my multi-year experience in product management and software development.

This proposal looks more like a project proposal rather than a challenge proposal. For example, from the definition of success "We got contract with a ERP for construction" and "We can get into 500 companies in 3 countries", it speaks about the activities of a single company/team, which makes the potential impact low with regards to the Fund8 strategic goals: grow the number of contrbutors, make Carano an open-source project, and grow the app and dev ecosystem.

Last but not least, even a broader challenge of building a CO2-registry can still perfectly fit within bigger DApps & Integrations challenges, so the community ROI from separating it is not clear.

I have made the following deductions:
- 2 points because this initiative does not support any of the strategic goals of Fund 8.
- 1 point for the lack of a discusion about specific use cases and their importance for Cardano ecosystem.
- 1 point for the lack of a clear analysis of alternative approaches to prove that focus on this user segment can bring high ROI to the community.
My rating is 1.
f6_assessments.q1:
Assuming a broader challenge of building a blockchain-based CO2-emissions registry, the Catalyst community is well positioned to propose and implement solutions for that.

However, because the challenge is formulated as a project for a single company and because it does not provide any references supporting the skills and the experience of the team, it looks risky.

I can suggest the following to improve the feasibility of the proposal:
1) Provide an overview the neccessary problems/use cases that need to be solved to have a registry that can cover 50+% of global CO2 emissions.
2) Provide examples of recent success stories with regards to tracking of CO2.
3) Discuss the funds and technologies necessary to track 5%, 25%, and 50% of global CO2 emissions.
4) Discuss best practices of cost-effective tracking of CO2

I have made the following deductions:
- 1 point for the lack of specific use cases.
- 1 point for the lack of a discussion about the sufficiency of the requested funds to achieve a noticeable impact.
- 1 point for the challenge team from one proposer, reducing the ability to provide advice and experience-based insights to participants.
My rating is 2.
f6_assessments.q2:
The suggested metrics (measure scope?, measure steel, measure cement) are ambiguously defined: what is scope? in which units to measure steel? would the steel be categoriezed based on % of carbon, etc?

Furthermore, the suggested metrics do now allow to track progress of the implied problem (the tracking of global CO2 emissions). Out of my product management experience, looking at some of the following metrics could make the proposal stronger:
1) % of the global CO2 emissions tracked.
2) the cost of tracking each incremental % of CO2 emissions.
3) % of Cardano users onboarded as part of  projects within this initiative.
4) the satisfaction of users/partners with the proposed solutions vs alternative ones.

I have made the following deductions:
- 1 point for the lack of metrics evaluating the relative impact on the Cardano ecosystem.
- 1 point for the lack of metrics evaluating user satisfaction and the competitiveness of the solutions.
My rating is 3.

f6_assessments.q0: There is no obvious alignment in this challenge to achieving Cardano's mission as defined by the Fund 8 challenge setting strategic goals. Statements tying the objectives back to the Cardano ecosystem should be included. To improve challenge: better articulate how the challenge aligns with 1 or more of the Fund 8 Strategic Goals.
f6_assessments.q1: This challenge is written as a proposal instead of a challenge fund. It probably should have been submitted as a proposal under the Miscellaneous challenge.
f6_assessments.q2: The key metrics and success criteria are ostensibly measurable however the phrasing could be improved. To make the challenge excellent: better articulate how the metrics can measure progress towards the success criteria.

f6_assessments.q0: This challenge proposal does not really sound lake a challenge proposal but like what was intended to be a proposal in the LATAM category. I am not sure the proposer is aware of that. At least nothing in this challenge proposal indicates that it was intended to provide a space for other proposals. While such a usecase would have a positive societal impact and also explore a new usecase for blockchain and Cardano, it is not formulated as a challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer does not seem to know the requirements of a challenge proposal, like metrics and success criteria FOR PROPOSALS , so I am not sure whether the challenge team (if there are any additional people apart from the proposer) can confidently manage this. This challenge proposal is not really open for various solutions as it is very concrete. Time cannot really be adressed here either, as the framework for proposals is non-existing in this challenge.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has not properly understood how to set up metrics for a challenge. What is in the proposal is not sufficient to enable proper auditability

f6_assessments.q0: This challenge definition is actually a project proposal. The challenge question is not a question but a problem description. The brief describes a generic solution, lacking a minimum level of details.
f6_assessments.q1: As not question and not guiding direction for proposers are included, this challenge will most likely not receive any good quality proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: Key metrics are not measurable, and not relevant to assess the success of the challenge. I disagree that the progress of this challenge -if voted- would be easy to estimate.

importance: ラテンアメリカの人々にとって、気候変動への対策はかなり遠いものです。環境に優しいプロジェクトを選択することで、解決の一端を担うことができるかもしれません。
